response.answer_text: Yes and no, depending on how you look at it.Science is not directly attacking religion, and in fact throughout time many historic scientists were deeply religious, and often even priests. Some relevant articles:List of Roman Catholic cleric-scientists Science in the medieval Islamic world The problem though lies in the foundational concepts of what religion and science is supposed to do. It's often quoted that "Science explains how, religion explains why".This is true to a point, and for a long time this allowed religion and science to happily coexist. The problem is that when science is not available, people turn to religion for answers. This is fine for some things, and I admit that religion can offer some confort for some. Unfortunately religious answers were also applied to the observable universe.   As science progresses and explains more and more of how the univese works and what "makes it tick", religion ans science were fated to come to a head. Now I'm pretty sure that Copernicus didn't intend to go head to head with the church.  He was just trying to solve the puzzle that the geocentric position that the church was teaching conflicted with his observations on the movement of the planets. He, like many scientists at the time, was trying to understand god's plans by understanding how he had shaped the earth and the heavens. His observation that the earth was not the centre of the universe contradicted what the church had been teaching for centuries and thus was undermining the "infallibility" of the church. Let's just say that the church did not respond gracefully. Ever since then, science and religion have been regularly colliding. Science is eternally building up a large body of work, checked and double-checked of observable facts, giving us a better and better understanding of the universe all the time. As a result, people don't have to trust in religion for their answers any more. As science progresses, claims of the supernatural are easily exposed as hoaxes. This has resulted in a sharp drop in the number of reported miracles in the past few centuries. In the end, religion is losing the conflict. Less and less people are concerning themselves with church. Science is providing the answers these days. Science has proven to cure more people than prayer. Various religious organisations have tried to deal with that in different ways.  Some try to provide a social function.Some try to unite their members in hate (like the Westboro Baptist Church) Others have decided to go head to head with science by promoting ignorance. In the end though, these actions are really just postponing the end result.Perhaps Religion will survive somehow. In which case I hope it will provide something positive. I doubt that it will ever have the power it had over us again though.
